**Mikhail Kalashnikov's Legacy: A Life of Guilt and Redemption**

Mikhail Kalashnikov, the inventor of the iconic AK-47 assault rifle, left behind a complex legacy before his death at the age of 94. In a letter written to the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill, Kalashnikov expressed his deep spiritual pain and guilt over the countless lives lost due to his invention. The letter, dated May 2012, was published by Izvestia, a pro-Kremlin daily, and reveals a man grappling with the moral implications of his creation.

Kalashnikov designed the AK-47 in 1947, inspired by his experiences in World War II, where he was wounded fighting for the Red Army. The rifle's simplicity, reliability, and affordability made it a widely used and manufactured weapon, with over 100 million sold worldwide. However, its use by terrorists, child soldiers, and other malicious actors has led to widespread suffering and death.

In his letter, Kalashnikov questioned whether he was responsible for the lives lost, despite his intention to design the rifle to defend his country. He wrote, "My spiritual pain is unbearable. I keep having the same unsolved question: if my rifle took away people's lives, then can it be that I... am guilty for people's deaths, even if they were enemies?" The letter, typed on his personal writing paper, is signed with a wavering hand, suggesting a man struggling with his conscience.

Kalashnikov's conversion to Christianity at the age of 91, and his baptism, may have contributed to his introspection and guilt. His daughter, Yelena, noted that while her father was not a devout Christian, he did have a deep respect for the faith. The Russian Orthodox Church, which has sought to consolidate its influence in Russia, responded to Kalashnikov's letter with a statement supporting the use of weapons to protect the Fatherland, while condemning their use by terrorists.

Kalashnikov's legacy is complex, marked by both pride and guilt. His invention has become an iconic symbol of armed insurgent movements, yet he himself struggled with the moral implications of its use. As the world continues to grapple with the consequences of violence and conflict, Kalashnikov's story serves as a poignant reminder of the human cost of war and the importance of accountability.

It contains this line: "I keep having the same unsolved question: if my rifle took away people's lives, then can it be that I ... am guilty for people's deaths, even if they were enemies?" AFP notes that Izvestia ran a copy of the letter, which is typed on Kalashnikov's personal stationery and signed "with a wavering hand." **Man Convicted in 1957 Cold Case Released from Prison After New Evidence Emerges**

McCullough was serving a life sentence for the crime, which was one of the oldest unsolved cases in the US to go to trial.

The case dates back to December 3, 1957, when Maria was abducted while playing in the snow with a friend in Sycamore, Illinois. Her body was found five months later, and despite a massive investigation, no one was ever charged in connection with her death until 2012, when McCullough was convicted of the crime.

However, new evidence has emerged that suggests McCullough may have been wrongly convicted. DeKalb County State's Attorney Richard Schmack conducted a six-month review of the case and concluded that McCullough could not have killed Maria. Schmack found that phone records supported McCullough's alibi, which was that he was in Rockford, Illinois, attempting to enlist in the US Air Force at the time of the abduction.

The new evidence includes records that show McCullough made a collect call to his parents at 6:57 p.m. from a phone booth in downtown Rockford, which is 40 miles northwest of where Maria was abducted. Schmack also reviewed police reports and hundreds of other documents, including from the Air Force recruitment office, which he said contained "a wealth of information pointing to McCullough's innocence, and absolutely nothing showing guilt."

The judge, William P. Brady, ruled that McCullough would be released from prison, citing the new evidence and the fact that McCullough's conviction was based on flawed testimony and improper legal rulings. McCullough's family was overjoyed by the news, while Maria's family remains convinced that he is guilty and has sought the appointment of a special prosecutor to keep him behind bars.

The case has been a source of pain and trauma for the Ridulph family for decades, and the reversal of McCullough's conviction has reopened old wounds. The case highlights the challenges of prosecuting cold cases, where evidence is often lost or destroyed, and memories fade over time.
answers: A man convicted four years ago in the oldest cold case ever tried was freed Friday after an Illinois judge vacated his conviction and subsequent life sentence, CNN reports. According to CBS News, 76-year-old Jack McCullough was convicted of kidnapping a 7-year-old girl, choking her, and stabbing her to death in 1957. The case was reopened in 2008, and McCullough was arrested in 2011 and convicted the following year. After an appeal by McCullough, Illinois state's attorney Richard Schmack launched a six-month investigation that found what he calls "clear and convincing evidence" that McCullough is innocent. While the judge Friday vacated McCullough's conviction, he stopped short of declaring him innocent, and a new trial will be held, the Chicago Tribune reports. McCullough, who lived in the same neighborhood as the kidnapped girl, says he was 40 miles away at an Air Force recruiting center at the time of the kidnapping. It's an alibi that passed a polygraph test in 1957 and made it impossible for him to be the culprit based on the FBI's original timeline for the kidnapping. That timeline was later changed by police, and Schmack says documents—including phone and Air Force records—supporting McCullough's alibi were wrongly not allowed at his trial. A friend of the kidnapped girl picked McCullough out of a photo lineup when the case was reopened. But his was the only non-yearbook photo in the lineup, and she picked a different man out of a photo lineup 50 years earlier. That info wasn't allowed at McCullough's trial either. No physical evidence was ever found to support McCullough's conviction.

**Cigarette Smoke Fuels the Growth of Superbugs: A Growing Concern**

Recent studies have revealed a disturbing link between cigarette smoke and the virulent rampage of superbugs, specifically Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Researchers at the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine have found that cigarette smoke not only harms human respiratory and immune cells but also makes MRSA more resistant to antibiotics and more aggressive in its invasion of human cells.

According to a study published in the journal Infection and Immunity, MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke extract becomes four times more resistant to macrophage killing and more resistant to antimicrobial peptides. This increased resistance allows the bacteria to repel common forms of immune responses, making it more difficult to treat. The study also found that the increased resistance continued for 24 hours after exposure, suggesting that it could be inherited.

In lab studies, MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke extract was found to be more aggressive and better at invading human cells. In fact, the smoke-exposed MRSA was able to kill more mice than non-exposed MRSA. This is a concerning finding, as MRSA is a type of bacteria that causes life-threatening infections to the skin, bloodstream, or a surgical site, and sometimes causes pneumonia.

The study's lead author, Dr. Laura E. Crotty Alexander, a pulmonologist at UCSD and the Veterans Affairs San Diego Healthcare System, stated that cigarette smoke exposure stresses MRSA, causing it to alter its cell walls to repel toxic substances. This enhances its survival against reactive oxygen species, which macrophages generate to kill pathogens.

The study's findings suggest that cigarette smoke functions like an alarm to the superbug MRSA, warning it to activate its defenses. This is a concerning finding, as cigarette smokers are already known to be more susceptible to infectious diseases. The study's results add yet another reason to why individuals should refrain from smoking.

In a related study, researchers found that e-cigarette vapor also makes MRSA more resistant, but to a lesser extent than cigarette smoke. The study suggests that cigarette smoke-induced resistance in MRSA may be an additional contributing factor to the increased susceptibility of smokers to infectious diseases.

The study's findings have significant implications for public health, as they suggest that cigarette smoke not only harms smokers but also makes pathogens more aggressive. The study's results highlight the need for continued research into the effects of cigarette smoke on human health and the development of new strategies to combat the growing threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria
answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. It's almost as if the smoke sets off an alarm that causes the bacteria to strengthen its defenses, explains the Union-Tribune of San Diego. Scientists made the discovery by exposing immune cells to two different batches of MRSA, one normal and one treated with cigarette smoke extract. The bigger the dose of smoke, the bigger the effect, notes Medical Daily. "We already know that smoking cigarettes harms human respiratory and immune cells, and now we've shown that, on the flipside, smoke can also stress out invasive bacteria and make them more aggressive," says lead author Laura Crotty Alexander of UC San Diego. It's a double-whammy: Smokers already have weakened immune systems that make them more susceptible to infectious diseases, and the smoke they inhale seems to make invading pathogens even more dangerous. In this study, the smoke helped MRSA survive longer and kill more mice with pneumonia. (The latest antibiotic-resistant bug to make headlines is a nasty stomach virus.)

By investing in inclusive education and healthcare, providing support to vulnerable families, and promoting family-based care alternatives, children can thrive within their own families and communities.

**Ancient Human Settlement in Australia Uncovered**

A groundbreaking discovery in the Flinders Ranges of southern Australia has revealed a human settlement dating back 49,000 years, challenging previous estimates of human arrival in the continent. The site, known as Warratyi rock shelter, contains a treasure trove of artefacts and bones, including the earliest known evidence of human interaction with megafauna.

**Discovery and Excavation**

The site was discovered by archaeologist Giles Hamm and local Adnyamathanha elder Clifford Coulthard while surveying the area. Excavations revealed over 4,300 artefacts and 200 bone fragments from 16 mammals and one reptile. The team used a combination of optical dating and radiocarbon dating to determine the age of the site, with results indicating human occupation between 49,000 and 46,000 years ago.

**Significance of the Find**

The discovery pushes back the earliest known dates for human settlement in the arid interior of Australia by 10,000 years, with previous estimates suggesting humans arrived around 38,000 years ago. The site also contains evidence of the earliest known use of ochre in Australia and South-East Asia, as well as the development of key technologies such as bone needles, wood-handled stone tools, and gypsum use.

**Evidence of Megafauna Interaction**

The site contains bones from the extinct giant wombat-like Diprotodon optatum and eggs from an ancient giant bird, suggesting that early humans were interacting with Australia's legendary megafauna. While it is unclear whether they were hunting them, the discovery provides significant evidence of human-megafauna interaction in the region.

**Impact on the Debate**

The find challenges the prevailing view that climate change was the primary cause of megafauna extinction, with some researchers suggesting that human hunting may have played a significant role. The discovery also challenges the Eurocentric view of Indigenous Australians as being less innovative than other populations.

**Importance of the Site**

The Warratyi rock shelter is considered one of the most important prehistoric sites in Australia, providing a unique window into the lives of early humans in the arid interior of the continent. The site is expected to be a significant milestone in the study of human history and the development of human culture in Australia.

"Nature called and Cliff walked up this creek bed into this gorge and found this amazing spring surrounded by rock art," Hamm says. At the time, Hamm thought the newly discovered human settlement, a site called Warratyi, was only 5,000 years old. It turns out it's closer to 49,000 years old, and that has huge ramifications for our knowledge of ancient Australian civilization, Sky News reports. Hamm and his team published a study on Warratyi this week in Nature. The discovery of Warratyi in the arid interior of the continent means humans either arrived in Australia up to 10,000 years earlier than previously believed—or they expanded across the continent at a much quicker rate, Science Alert reports. Researchers at the site found 4,300 objects, including tools, and 200 bone fragments from multiple animals, including a 5,500-pound marsupial. The bones help explain how early Australians interacted with megafauna, including hunting them. The tools show Australians were using bone and stone axes earlier than believed and are evidence that early Australians developed some technologies on their own rather than adopting them from other peoples as previously believed. answers: There are more obese or overweight people in the world today than there were people of any weight in 1935, the most comprehensive look at worldwide obesity in decades warns. Not a single country has recorded a decline in obesity over the last 30 years. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," a study co-author says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." Egypt is in the midst of its final round of voting in the first parliamentary elections since the ouster of former President Hosni Mubarak in February. The elections, which began in November, have seen Islamist groups, particularly the Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice party, gain significant ground. The Brotherhood is expected to consolidate its lead in the final round, which covers nine provinces, including the North and South Sinai governorates.

The elections come as prosecutors are presenting their case against Mubarak, who is on trial for corruption and conspiring to kill protesters. The chief prosecutor, Mustafa Suleiman, accused Mubarak of imposing "tyrannical rule" and devoting the last decade of his rule to ensure his son, Gamal, would succeed him. Suleiman also criticized Mubarak's regime for corruption, particularly in the lead-up to the anti-Mubarak uprising in January last year.

The Brotherhood has played down its electoral strength, but analysts suggest that it could win a clear majority of seats in the new parliament. This would enable the Brotherhood to govern without forming a coalition, reducing the power of ultraconservative Islamists and liberal parties. The Brotherhood has stated that it intends to form a coalition or unity government to avoid unnerving Egyptian liberals and Westerners who fear an Islamist takeover.

The elections have been marked by controversy, with the military rulers refusing to cede power before presidential elections are held by the end of June. The ruling generals have scheduled the first session of the new parliament for January 23, two days before the anniversary of the outbreak of protests that ousted Mubarak. The lower house of Parliament is Egypt's primary legislative body, and the military rulers have said they intend to retain authority over the hiring and firing of a prime minister to run the interim government.

The trial of Mubarak and his two sons, Gamal and Alaa, has resumed after a two-month hiatus. The prosecution will present its case over the next three days, with Mubarak facing charges of complicity in the killing of over 800 protesters. The two sons face corruption charges, and Mubarak could face the death penalty if convicted.

The elections and Mubarak's trial come as Egypt's economy struggles, with growth slowing due to unrest and a decline in foreign-currency reserves. The benchmark EGX 30 stock index has lost 49 percent last year, making it the third-worst performer among world markets tracked by Bloomberg.

A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far.
